data.title: Test commit for MonoGameTeam. Added comments to MathHelper.
data.body: Hello - I made first test commit for MonoGame. So, I added comments to MathHelper so this important class now fully commented. Accept this or decline if you dont like it.

data.title: Add built-in System and Math content type writers
data.body: Reader type is now correctly derived from writer type for built-in types.

data.title: Small MGCB Fixes
data.body:
Two small MGCB fixes:
- Errors now go to stderr.
- Added missing #if WINDOWS.

data.title: sound glitches
data.body:
I have an strange behaviour with monogame 2.6 on iOS. My game load a texture2D, and then display it. It loads a new texture from disk every 1/12th second ( i can not load all the textures in memory because of there are a lot of frames)

So, the logic es:
Load frame if necessary
Play sound if necessary
Draw Texture
Draw a button texture ( loaded in memory previously)

Running the game, the sound make 'glitches', and, curiously, slows down!! But the display sow the images perfectly, without problem
If i comment the loading line, the sound is perfect, but nothing is displayed, of course.

But then i tried another scenary: 
Load frame if necessary
Play sound if necessary
 // Draw Texture
Draw a button texture ( loaded in memory previously)

And this work fine too!! So it seems that the problem is that there is not enough 'time' for the sound player to update?

Do you know how to solve this? Thanks!!

Post: i've tried with WAV, mp3 and aac, and ...it performs worst with WAV!!!

data.title: DXT Compression implemented
data.body:
DXT compression has been implemented with Nvidia's Texture Tools library. The current trunk does not have functional C# bindings, so I've fixed them and submitted the patch to their Google Code page. Hopefully they'll quickly integrate them in so we don't have to fork and maintain the NVTT separately.

NVTT is supposed to support Windows, OSX and Linux, but I'm only able to build and test it for Windows. Hopefully we'll be able to use similar if not identical bindings?

We'll also be using NVTT for good mipmap generation, rather than having different implementations across platforms.

data.title: Song Support for WinDX
data.body:
Adding of the rather complex MediaSession song support for the Windows desktop DirectX platform.
- Implemented play/pause/stop/resume/mute/volume for Song.
- Made a few non-XNA Song members internal.
- The Song.FilePath is now absolute for desktop & WinRT systems.

The end of song events are not currently working... I need to get a fix into SharpDX before I can correct that still.

data.title: (Jan MSI release) Incorrect mapping of SDL.DLL file in "Windows OpenGL" project template
data.body:
If you start up a new "Windows OpenGL" project in VS 2010 there is a file that is incorrectly referenced called SDL.DLL

Unsure at this point whether is should be an actual reference or a linked file as it is now.

In either case the project template refers to:

"C:\users<username>\Program Files (x86)\MonoGame\v3.0\Assemblies\WindowsGL\SDL.dll"

Where it should point to:

"C:\Program Files (x86)\MonoGame\v3.0\Assemblies\WindowsGL\SDL.dll"
Like the rest of the MonoGame delivered DLL's

![MonoGameSDL error](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1793042/116420/4f06ae54-6bf8-11e2-867f-253a70afcf58.png)

data.title: iOS SoundEffect Duration Error
data.body:
When I try to run soundeffect, MonoDevelop throws in MonoGame / Freamework / MacOS / Audio / SoundEffect.cs this error:

System.DivideByZeroException has been thrown

in this line:

_dblDuration = var (e.Bytes / ((asbd.BitsPerChannel / 8) \* asbd.ChannelsPerFrame)) / asbd.SampleRate;

Any help?

data.title: Portrait Rotation issue on Windows 8 Surface
data.body:
I got this report from a user
"I recently ran into another issue that might be related to the resolution issue with the Surface.  When I run on a monitor that has been rotated into portrait mode the graphics device settings look like they're based on the unrotated values.  The resulting image ends up getting stretched to/squashed to fit the rotated aspect ratio."

This is the test app which demos the problem,

https://dl.dropbox.com/u/18881050/bug.zip

To show the problem you can either run it on a monitor that has been rotated into portrait mode or run it on the Win8 Surface simulator with that rotated.  NOTE that you need to do the rotation before starting the app.

data.title: Windows Phone 8 - TouchLocation giving invalid positions
GraphicsCapabilites.GetNonPowerOfTwo(device) NullReferenceException
data.body:
On line 84 of GraphicsCapabilites.cs for MacOS X,

```
GL.GetInteger(GetPName.MaxTextureSize, out maxTextureSize);
```

System.NullReferenceException is thrown. It seems GetPName.MaxTextureSize is null here. Commenting out this line temporarily solves the issue but hinders development for those using non-power-of-two textures.

data.body:
On line 84 of GraphicsCapabilites.cs for MacOS X, 

```
GL.GetInteger(GetPName.MaxTextureSize, out maxTextureSize);
```

System.NullReferenceException is thrown. It seems GetPName.MaxTextureSize is null here. Commenting out this line temporarily solves the issue but hinders development for those using non-power-of-two textures.

data.title: Bug inside SoundEffectInstance.
RenderTarget2D doesn't work on PlayStation Mobile
data.body: It's fine that this class doesn't work, but it and associated methods (SetRenderTarget for example) should probably throw. I spent a while confused by garbled/uninitialized image data.

data.title: SpriteBatch devours memory
data.body:
The default buffer size for SpriteBatch (10000 vertices/draw calls respectively) is too high and makes it difficult to use on PlayStation Mobile - being generous, that's at least a megabyte of memory (104 bytes per SpriteBatchItem, not even counting runtime overhead since it's a class...) which easily can run you up against the memory limit on that platform (it's 96MB total, for everything, including textures and buffers).

I don't know what the right buffer size is, though.

data.title: Fix for WinGL initialising GraphicsCapabilities
data.body: Seems that my last pull request broke WindowsGL, and possibly Mac and Linux too. For some reason calling `GL.GetInteger(GetPName.MaxTextureSize, out maxTextureSize);` from a static method causes a null reference exception in OpenTK. I've worked around it by caching the _maxTextureSize in Graphics device. I've also move the parsing of GL extensions to their own method and moved it to constructor after the other 'GL.GetInteger' calls.

data.title: Windows 8: Texture2D.GetData does not work on all GPUs
Even More MGCB Improvements
data.body:
This I think is the final round of MGCB improvements before I start looking at hooking it into MSBuild and Visual Studio.
- Added target /platform, /profile, and /config options.
- Added /incremental build flag to skip cleaning files not in current build.
- /clean now works as we know the previously built content.

data.title: [MacOS] Added an optional Delegate to GameWindow
data.body: Added an optional Delegate to GameWindow to allow custom GameWindow implementations to be used.

data.title: Fix a runtime error when getting GraphicsCapabilites in Linux
data.body: This fixes a bug introduced with the new GraphicsCapabilities class. It was trying to use the ES20 namespace in the desktop environments.

data.title: Ignore mip maps for non power of two textures when device doesn't support them
data.body:
Added a GraphicsCapabilities class to test for non-power of two texture support. In the future this can be extended to test for other things.

This feature is important because when you supply non PoT mip maps and the device doesn't support them, you will GL errors. Also, on Android some devices support them and others don't, meaning you may test your game and have it work fine but once released it will crash on other devices.

The support for mip maps with non-PoT textures is patchy, but more and more devices have support so it'd be a shame to disable it outright.

So far I've tested on an iPad 1, Windows 7, Android 4.0 Samsung GalaxyS2, and a MacBook (not pro).

The only part I'm not confident about is the handling of OPENGL non-GLES platforms (ie desktop PC, Mac and Linux). I took the advice given here: http://aras-p.info/blog/2012/10/17/non-power-of-two-textures/ (OpenGL section), which suggests a more reliable way of deciding on PoT support is whether the card supports 8192 sized textures. This is pretty safe. The only risk is that certain older devices that don't support 8192 textures but do fully support non-PoT textures will have their non-PoT mip maps discarded. Not likely to be a problem IMO as non PoT textures are mostly for UI elements and not likely to have mip maps anyway.

data.title: Support for all PixelFormats
data.body:
Note: This should be merged after PR #https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1252

Input now supports all pixel formats, rather than ARGB32 and RGB32.

data.title: Ignore nonpow2 mipmaps
data.body: This is an exact duplicate of https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1033 to see if it can be merged.

data.title: Added events for KeyUp and KeyDown
data.body:
The KeyUp and KeyDown methods are very important for low level keyboard
access but in MonoGame the general solution of overriding the view
cannot be done so I expose both as events.
